definitions.definition: a very short period of time

examples.text: Could you **wait a moment**, please?
**One moment, please** *(= Please wait a short time)*.
He thought for a moment before replying.
For one brief moment I thought, ‘I can handle this.’
I'll be back in a moment.
Have you got a moment?
This won't take a moment.
We arrived **not a moment too soon** *(= almost too late)*.
**Moments later** *(= a very short time later)*, I heard a terrible crash.
A moment later, the ceiling fell in.
After a moment we followed him.
Could you look through this report when you have a spare moment?
Could you wait a few moments?
He was here just a moment ago.
I can only spare you a moment, I'm afraid—I'm terribly busy.
I couldn't stand it a moment longer.
I spent a few moments thinking what I was going to say.
I stood there for a moment or two.
She paused a moment to reflect.
The feeling only lasted a moment.
There was a moment of silence.
in her rare moments of leisure

definitions.definition: an exact point in time
definitions.sensetop: at the momentin a moment of somethingFrom that moment on

examples.text: We're busy at the moment *(= now)*.
**At that very moment**, the phone rang.
You need to be aware of what you are doing **at any given moment**.
I agreed in a moment of weakness.
From that moment on, she never felt really well again.
at the moment of death
I dread the moment when she finds out.
She let the news slip by mistake, in an unguarded moment.
At the present moment, we do not have a choice.
For one heart-stopping moment, we thought she was going to fall.
I loved her from the first moment I met her.

definitions.definition: a good time for doing something; an opportunity

examples.text: I'm waiting for **the right moment** to tell him the bad news.
Have I caught you at a bad moment?
I haven't finished. I'm still waiting for a quiet moment.
We have reached a critical moment in the negotiations.
I don't think this is the right moment to ask for a bonus.
I didn't want to screw up my big moment.
The moment had finally come to make a move.
He opened his mouth to say he loved her, but the moment passed.
He's in a bad mood today—you need to choose your moment carefully.

definitions.definition: a particular time in somebody's life, or in the course of an event or the development of something

examples.text: That was one of the happiest moments of my life.
Her finest moment came when she won Wimbledon.
The film has many memorable moments.
a great moment in the country's history
This referendum is a **defining moment** for our nation.
I managed to **capture the moment** on film.
Enjoy your moment of fame!
Victory was sweet, and he wanted to savour every moment.
Afterwards she relived every moment in her head.
It was the proudest moment of my entire life.
I treasure the moments we spent together.
That was a bad moment in my life.
They were making the most of those last precious moments together.
This is one of the book's funniest moments.

definitions.definition: very soon

examples.text: Hurry up! He'll be back any moment now.
He might wake up at any moment.

definitions.definition: not long in advance; without warning or time for preparation

examples.text: This was the best room we could get at such short notice.
You must be ready to leave at a moment's notice.
It's the best we can do at such short notice.
The team is ready to go anywhere in the world at a moment's notice.

definitions.definition: now, at the present time

examples.text: At this moment in time, I don't know what my decision will be.

definitions.definition: to be popular for a short time (used about something that is not usually popular)

examples.text: The previously unfashionable Tyrol is currently having a moment.
Classic '70s hairstyles are having a moment once more.

definitions.definition: to not act normally for a short time, for example when you forget where you are or what you are doing

examples.text: Sorry, I was just having a moment. What time is it?

definitions.definition: to have a short argument or romantic exchange

examples.text: Oh, sorry—were you two having a moment?

definitions.definition: for now; for a short time

examples.text: This house is big enough for the moment, but we'll have to move if we have children.

definitions.definition: to have short times that are better, more interesting, etc. than others

examples.text: The job isn't exciting all the time, but it has its moments.
I found the play rather boring, but it had its moments.

definitions.definition: completely mentally involved in what you are doing or experiencing

examples.text: The time goes so quickly—you just have to remember to stay in the moment.

definitions.definition: used to ask somebody to wait for a short time

examples.text: ‘Is Mr Burns available?’ ‘Just a second, please—I'll check.’

definitions.definition: the latest possible time before an important event

examples.text: They changed the plans at the last minute.
Don't leave your decision to the last moment.
Don't leave everything till the last minute.
Why do you leave it until the last possible moment before getting ready to leave?

definitions.definition: as soon as…

examples.text: I want to see him the moment he arrives.
The moment she walked through the door I thought she looked different.
I felt at home here from the very moment I arrived.

definitions.definition: a time when somebody/something is tested, or when important decisions are made

examples.text: The moment of truth is when the trainee pilots take over the controls of the plane.

definitions.definition: certainly not; not at all

examples.text: I don't think for a moment that she'll accept but you can ask her.

definitions.definition: very important

examples.text: matters of great moment

definitions.definition: famous, important and talked about a lot now

examples.text: She's the fashion designer of the moment.

definitions.definition: suddenly, without planning in advance

examples.text: I phoned him up on the spur of the moment.
a spur-of-the-moment decision

definitions.definition: the best time to do something in order for it to be successful

examples.text: The trick is in finding the (right) psychological moment to ask him for more money.

definitions.definition: to wait for a short time

examples.text: Can you wait a moment while I make a call?
Hey! Wait a minute! I'll come with you!

definitions.definition: used when you have just noticed or remembered something, or had a sudden idea

examples.text: Wait a moment—this isn't the right key.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin momentum, from movimentum, from movere ‘to move’.
